Primo Levi.desc: When Italy declares war on Britain and France as an ally of Germany in 1940, Primo Levi is studying Chemistry in the University of Turin. Since 1948, Jews had lost civil rights and were not allowed to enter university. However, those already studying were allowed to continue and Levi enrolled a year early, permitting him to carry on his studies.

After graduating in 1941 it's difficult for Levi to find a permanent job due to the racial laws. He obtains a job offer to work as a chemist at an asbestos mine under a false identity. His job is to extract nickel from spoil. Later he understands that if successful he would be helping the Germans, who had shortages of nickel for making weapons.
Three months later, in 1942, Levi's father dies and he moves to try and find work in Milan.
While in Milan he is recruited to work for a Swiss company. He isn't subject to the racial laws while there.

In 1943 King Victor Emmanuel III removes Mussolini from power and appoints a new government that prepares to sign an armistice with the Allies. When this is made public German forces occupy north and central Italy. Levi returns to find his mother and sister in refuge in their holiday home outside the city.

As Jews are being arrested they flee to Amay where they believe they could hide. The Italian resistance movement becomes more and more active in the German-occupied zone, and Levi attempts to form a small resistance group with some others. They are soon arrested by the Fascist militia.

He is told that he will be shot as an Italian partisan, at which point he confesses to being a Jew. He is transported to Fossoli internment camp. He isn't harmed because the camp is under the control of the Italian Social Republic, a puppet government, rather than Nazi Germany.

When the Nazis take over Fossoli they start transporting Jews to death camps. Levi leaves on the 21st of Feburary 1944 heading for Monowitz, part of the Auschwitz concentration camp. Of the 650 Italian Jews in the twelve cattle trucks with him only 24 are to leave the death camps alive. Levi knows some German and he pays a more experienced inmate in bread for German lessons, which aids his survival.

He forms a friendship with bricklayer Lorenzo Perrone when he overhears him speaking Piemontese. Perrone gives him bread and the remainder of his ration every day for six months, and also provides him with clothes he can wear under his uniform to survive the cold.

In November 1944 his Chemistry degree gets him a position as an assistant at IG Farben's Buna-Werke laboratory. This means that he avoids having to do hard labour outdoors in freezing conditions, and also allows him to steal materials and trade them for food.

Levi falls ill with scarlet fever and is moved to the infirmary. As the Soviets draw nearer to the camp, on the 18th of January 1945, the Germans take all of the prisoners who are able to walk on a death march and abandon the rest. Levi's sickness saved him from having to go on this march which very few survived.
After the camp is liberated and after he recovers from his illness, Levi moves to a transfer camp for displaced people run by the Russians in Katowice and awaits his repatriation.
On June 30th Levi leaves the transfer camp in a troop train headed for Odessa with 800 other Italians. They travel East to Zhmerynka.
Although they planned to head South to Odessa, they are forced to take the train North to Slutsk.
From there Levi walks and rides a horse cart to the Krasny Dom displaced persons camp in Staryya Darohi, where he works as a medical assistant.

After two months at the camp Russian marshal Semyon Timoshenko arrives and announces that the displaced people can begin making their way home. Levi begins his train journey back to Italy on the 15th of September.
Levi heads South and by the 23rd of September he has reached southern Romania.
Next he proceeds West through Hungary and into Slovakia, reaching Bratislava by the 7th of October.
By the 15th of October he has reached Munich after travelling through Austria into Germany.
He's reached Verona back in Italy by the 17th of October.

Finally, on the 19th of October 1945, he arrives back in Turin after 20 months away. Over the coming months he spends time recovering, making contact with surviving friends and family, and looking for work. In January 1946 he starts working for a paint factory outside Turin. The poor train services means that he stays in the factory dormitory during the week: here he starts to write the first draft of If This Is a Man.
This is only a brief overview of some of the events that happened. You can read the full story in Primo Levi's books 'If This Is a Man' and 'The Truce'.
